results.title: Slow Service
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour, silent
results.brief_description:
‘Slow Service’ is a series of portraits shot using a high speed video camera. This camera, which is normally used for filming mine detonations, science experiments and military tests, captures 1000 frames a second. The footage, when played back at 25 frames per second, has been slowed down so that a second of real time takes forty seconds on the screen. ‘I asked the subjects to pose as if for a passport photograph. We see the transition between this artificial pose and their natural instinctive reaction to the bucket of food that is being thrown at them, and then the impact of the food itself.

I liked the idea of capturing a wasteful, slapstick, human gesture using a medium that is normally reserved for ‘serious’ scientists and bomb designers’. (Marcus Lyall, 2004)

results.title: Fast film
results.brief_description: This ingenious cut out animation is the chase film to end all chase films. Borrowing images and characters from various Hollywood classics, ‘Fast film’ then distorts and twists our understanding of where these icons of Hollywood folklore belong. Ultimately mutating into a new narrative where the suave Cary Grant and Frankenstein’s monster happily co-exist side by side.

results.title: Carmel: storyteller
results.brief_description: Carmel is a retired school teacher, wife, mother and grandmother. Her family’ s life dramatically changed when she was diagnosed with early onset memory loss. With her husband, she tells their story and looks positively in the face of an unknown future. Created as part of the ‘Memory’s Voice: Capturing Stories of Courage’ workshop, an ACMI Digital Storytelling Project in association with Alzheimer’s Australia Vic and in partnership with VicHealth.

results.title: Bolgene
results.brief_description: Two young men who have been boyhood friends for years are taking their regular holiday together on a Scandanavian island. However, with approaching adulthood, the sexual tensions in their relationships begin to emerge. This is a serious and beautifully crafted story about adolescence and innocence, and the inevitability of change. By concentrating on the physicality and intimacy of the two male bodies in space, Mosvold creates a haunting, resonating work.

results.title: Hello
results.brief_description: ‘Hello’ is it me you’re looking for?’ A wildly imaginative love story about love across the digital-analogue divides. Can an almost obsolete cassette head speak the language of love with only fast forward and rewind to work with?
